titleStmt.title: M51. Anon. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. correction on p. 3, unsigned and undated. 9p. Wanting p. 1. Paginated 2-10
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M51. Anon. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. correction on p. 3, unsigned and undated. 9p. Wanting p. 1. Paginated 2-10

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p: 2 Anon.
common voice singing out of doors. he has no house. He lives a roaming life, crossing the fields, moutning (mounting) the hills, and lying down by the hawthown to listen to te (the) nightingale.

Still, by shutting out a chimey (chimney) or a bungalow we can see what saw-- the bird haunted reed whispering fen, the down, and the green scar never healed along which he came when he made his journeys. He was a simp le (simple) singer, lifting a song or a story from other peoples lips, and lettig (letting) the auience (audience) join in the chours (chorus). Sometimes he made a few lines that exactly matchedhis (matched his) emtoin (emotion)--he was an arist (artist).
But there is no name to that song.
When at last the house was built, he song (sung) only at the back door. Upstairs they spoke French; his song was sung in English; and the words were so uncouth
Icham for woing al forwake Wery no water in wore
that they n ed (need) a ditioc nary (dictionary) now.]
Icham for woing al forwake Wery no water in wore

Bu (But) to the listener then, to for xample (example) in his
pasronage (parsonage), they were not only difficult. They were painful. They reminded him of his lack of intellectual [illeg.] His intellectual pedigree reached vack (back) only to , , a bare hundre (hundred) and fifty years. To have anscestors (ancestors) he must ross (cross) the . His ancestors by way of the mind are Greeks and Rla ns (Romans). His page is

bu dened (burdened) with protesttaions (protestations) og (of) good breeding--
; , ; --xxxxxxx ixx quotes them to prove his good breeding as we to prove ours quote the Elizabthans (Elizabethans).

was not a respecable (respectable) ancestor. He was nameless because he was disrputable (disreputable). Even the Kings and Queens must have their sin ers (singers), their mistrels (minstrels), their xxxxxxx actors. But he was despised. Did he not feeling himself an outcast, use the outsiders privilege of irreponsible (irresponsible) mockery? Hewas tolerated, as we tolerate those who say out loud what we think, but will not admit. So he sang, danced
uggled (juggled) and led his bears to the back doot (door). He sings to serving men and maids. He tells them what they have heard
aldready (already)--old stories in inm hose (in those) choruses they can join. When the great Elizabethan house was built, he was still nameless, disreptuable (disreputable), the prason (parson) of in instead of setting down those ongs (songs), digs up coins. He already s s (sees) the present against the past. The past has become so settled that yhe (the) present looks
ngainly (ungainly) and d g n rate (degenerate) against it. There is too much comfort, too many pi ows (pillows), too many chimneys. The young and are not the men their fathers were. The msmoke (smoke) drawn up by the chimeys (chimneys) no lo ger (longer) hardens them. They are tender and subject to rheumatism. They dress
fantatically (fantastically) compared with their ancestor.s (ancestors.) It does not occur to him to set down the songs that were being sung, to describe the pagentatns , (pageants,) the mu ming (mumming), the plays that the wandering mistrels (minstrels) enacted. The English past served only to show the material change-- the change tha (that) had come over

houses, furinture (furniture) clothing½ (clothing) There was no English literature to show up the change in the mind. There were no English
boo s (books) to show up the decline of English writing.

Up stairs in the great room, as Ha ison (Harrison) tells us, "...our ancient ladies of the co rt (court)" we e (were) to be found reading the Gekks (Greeks) and Latins as they sat at their needlwork (needlework). xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx Greek and Latin came as easily to their pens as English. At
isnatnec (instance) sat writing to her son. Her letters might have been sermons from the pulpit. Shxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx She exhorst (exhorted); she admonsihed (admonished). Fear of God, suspcion (suspicion) of man surround her with the walls of a dungeon. There is no gaiety, no familiarity, no intimacy in this world. hw (She) draoes (drapes) herself in the langauge (language) of the B le (Bible) when she writes; and it is a garment only to fit a certain attitude. Save for and and the voice of singing at the back door, making his irrevent (irreverent) mockeries xmxmxmxmxmx the English might be a dumb race; a race of merchants soliders (soldiers) priests, who left ehind (behind) them stone houses cultivated fields and many churches, but no words. The great house is sielnt (silent). We can see it still, satnding (standing) in its green island of park, seaparated (separated) often from the high road, only by a dip in the ground and a low red wall. It is out of porpotion (proportion) now; iether (either) it is too large or the village with its bungalwos (bungalows) and shops is too small. The furn (furniture) is in exsitnce (existence) too. Inside all is kept as if the Queen were expected. The up right Elizabethan chairs stand round the walls. Their fringes and their tap st y (tapestry) is not much faded The oak tables are heavy and polished. The floor is str wn (strewn)

The oak tables are heavy and polished. The floor is laid with rugs; cut glass chand liers (chandeliers) hang down from the decorated plaster work of the celing (ceiling). Kick kncaks (Knick knacks) have survid (survived) an inlaid work box, an old doublet; and the pear shaped lute that the once played.

But of (if) the great Elizabethna (Elizabethan) house looks to us out of proportion, a derelict among the bungalows, it is b cause (because) the connection between it and the village is lost. If we could see the great house as it was in time we should see tracks raying out from the great house across the fields to the cottage, to the farm, even to the hovel. Paths were worn by the fighters; and the ploughers. They must be armed against other men. They must plough and sow together if they were not to starve in winter This connection isbetween (between) master and man is pa nfully (painfully)
minutelt recoredc (minutely recorded) in the medieval letters. I Its is (It is) the stape (staple) of th (the) whole correspondence between of and the and the of . But there was also the other less visibl (visible) connection--the common belief. That bond between the houses has been gorwn (grown) over, li e (lies) the track along which the rode to . Nobody rides there now. But when made is (his) that track led from house to house. It led to the village green; it led to the tree; to the welll (well). In the spring they danced round the maypole; in at midsummer they
llit (lit) the bon fire on the hill. At christmas the mummers acted their dumb shows; and the boys came wassiling (wassailing). The road led to the old Kings graces, to the stones

where the old pagan English had done sacrifice. The peasants still went that way by instinct, in spring and summer and winer. The old Gods lay hideen (hidden) beneath the new. If they were nameless now, it was to them, not to the Christian God, that the peants (peasants) did homage; wearing their green leaves to propittte (propagate) the earth Goddess; dancing through the houses; killing the old; reviving the new.

It is in the twenty one books of the that we tap into the deep resev ir (reservoir) of common belief that sunk , in the minds of the nobles and peasants. It is in pages that we hear the voice of
murmurinf (murmuring) still. Kings and Queens, nobles and peasnts (peasants) remembered how the old King and his knights went their ways through the wild woods seeking adventure. When himself doubted if any such man had ever been, the gentlemen of England were positive. They said that you could see skull at ; and the at ; and "in otherplaces sword and many other things." Txxxxxxxxxxxxxx In time a silv r (silver) horse shoe had been found at . The book comes to at the very moment when the old stories were fading. It xxxxxxxxx is half fable, half fact. There is ; and and ; there is the and . But the roads lead past London to cast s where Knights lie enchanted; down the roads ride for Queens on white mules; turns herself suddenly to stone; and a hand rises from a lake holding . Itis (It is) a childs story, in the

simplicity of its belief. It is a chi s (child's) story in its particularity. Beauty is stated, not suggested. So he went
in and searched from chamber to chamber, and found his bed, but she was ot (not) here; then Balin looked into a little garden, and under a laurel tree e sae (he saw) her lie upon a quilt of green samite and a knght with her, and under their heads
grasa (grass) and herbs."

But, save that self oncsiousnes (consciousness) has not yet raised its mirror, it is not a childs world. The men and women are corrupt already in this fresh world. They have evil dreams. is doomed. reat ki gs (Great kings) are undone by their own vices. The Quuens (Queens) are lustful. Still we can revsit (revisit) their world. But of the wr ter (writer) nothing is known. is not distinct from his book. It is still the voice of , speaking to the voice of anon. The dream is still dreamt. "...folks do say" a peasnt (peasant) at said in the ninenenth (nineteenth) century, "that on the night of the full moon King Arthur and his men ride round the hill, and their horses are shod with silver..."

, printing the at the solitictaion (solicitation) of the nobles and the gentry, had his doubts. Anon wxxxx still existsed (existed) but a shade has fallen upo (upon) him. The printed book with its writers name attached to was destined to kill him. After that, the audience became separate from the singer. And the audeince (audience) no longer took part in the song
supp ied (supplied) the story, filled in the pauses, and added sometimes a nonsensical chorus. The printed book seapareted (separated) from the voice and was read by those who could afford to buy them. The great read them in the great rooms. "I spent most of

my time" wrote playing at Clecko
and hearing read the ... used to
r ad (read) to me in and Moll Neville in the ."

The book must find its way into the hall, into the great room where novles (nobles) and genrty (gentry) have liesure (leisure) to read after the busniess (business) and the sport of the day is over. And with the printed book, the writer at last comes into existence--the writer wxxxxx who, unl e (unlike) the mistrel (minstrel), has a name; whose words are printed. He is in being after 1477 but he stillundiffrentiated (is still undifferentiated), limited. For when familiar letters are written in Biblical prose, only in emergency there must be a barrier between the sayable and the unsayable a limit to what can be put into words. The artist-- who stands outside, by some impulse desiring to observe and to state rather than to take part, is not wholly writer, wholly musician or wholly painter. It seems possible that the great English art may not b (be) the art of letters. ry (Every) word is read aloud; every word is given weight and edge by the speaking voice. And then the lute, the virginals the (they) gave lilt, rhymn (rhythm) and melody ot the written word. When in 1666 the london was burning and the citizens were loading their goods into boats noted that "hardly
one lighter or boat in threee (three) that had the goods of a house in it, but there was a pair of virginals in it."
Music, and the speaking voice lay beneath the words; and the words themselves were elastic. No grammar bound them tightly together. They could be danced to and sung to. Neverh (Nevertheless)
theless (Nevertheless), they could not follow the speaking voice, that voice that talks briefly, colloquially. The audience is speechless.

the n (then), standing on the threshold of the great room at --"a little man with short hair, a small band and cuffs"--- was separate from Anon the
misntrel (minstrel); separate from Holingshed (Holinshed) the chorniclaer (chronicler); and separate, in that he saw the scene with detachment and wished to record it, fro (from) his audie ce (audience). But the book which had given his word a separate exsience (existence), had brought into being a little group of readers. That influence, unknown to Anon, began at once to exert its pressure. What is he (the) poem that will please ? What is the theme that will flatter the ? What will so flatter the audience that they will procure for the poet a place, a pension? From this tiem (time) onward these are to be among the influences that tug, that distort, that twart (thwart); as also they stimulate, and draw out. There are some among them that the writer only reaslies (realises); others that the readers in time to come discover. More and more complex do t ey (they) grow, as t e (the) book with the authors name on it
r aches (reaches) a more various a more divided audi ce (audience). The the public insists; it wants, according to its welah (wealth) and its
poeverty (poverty), its education or irgnoarnce, (ignorance), now hist ry (history) now meloframa (melodrama), now powtry (poetry), now whatever will make it forget its drab and dismal existence. As the book becomes more and more aware of these infl unces (influences) the thing that the writer

More and more deflected by these infleunces (influences), the thing that the writer has to say becomes increasingly cumbered. It is only to be dsicover d (discovered) in flash intuiton (intuition). Thus some say that their beards bristle when they come upon it; others that a thrill runs down the nerves of the thigh. To disengag (disengage) the song from its encumbrances becomes as time goes on a task for the critic--that sp cially (specially) equipped taster who was not in existence when stood on the threshold of the great room at .
It was still connected with the village.
